channel.title: About on J. D. Mitchell
channel.description: Recent content in About on J. D. Mitchell

item.title: Resources for the Digraphs minicourse
item.description:
This page contains some resources for the Digraphs minicourse at GAP days Summer 2025 in Koper, Slovenia.

Here are the slides (pdf), and the worksheet worksheet (pdf).

Some data for the problems on the worksheet can be found below.

  • Aubrey de Grey’s graph showing that the chromatic number of the plane is at least $5$ in graph6 format: degrey.s6.gz
  • representatives of prime $\mathscr{J}$-classes in the boolean matrix monoid: n = 4, n = 5, n = 6, n = 7
  • erdos.s6.gz and labels.txt.gz.

item.title: An implementation of the Todd-Coxeter algorithm in python3
item.description: This page is a companion to the paper The Todd-Coxeter Algorithm for Semigroups and Monoids by T. D. H. Coleman, J. D. Mitchell, F. L. Smith, and M. Tsalakou. On this page we give an implementation of the two strategies for congruence enumeration described in the paper in python3. The code on this page is expository, and should probably not be used for anything serious. There are many optimization that could be applied, but we opted not to do these in order to keep the code short. Many best practices for software development, such as argument checks, assertions, docstrings or exceptions, are also absent, please forgive us in advance. The C++ library libsemigroups contains optimized versions of the code on this page, and we recommend you use this instead!

item.title: About
item.description:
This is the webpage of James D. Mitchell. I am a professor of mathematics at the School of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of St Andrews. I’m currently interested in computational semigroup theory, and topological algebra.

The website accompanying the paper ‘Groups that together with any transformation generate regular semigroups or idempotent generated semigroups’ by J. Araújo, J. D. Mitchell and Csaba Schneider is available here.

Address

Mathematical Institute,
North Haugh,
St Andrews,
Fife,
KY16 9SS,
Scotland.

item.title: Publications
item.description:
A list of publications by J. D. Mitchell on MathSciNet.

See Articles and Preprints.

item.title: The number of monogenic subsemigroups of the full transformation monoid
item.description:
Mathematics

In this post we show how to count the number of monogenic subsemigroups of the full transformation monoid up to isomorphism.

Throughout this post, we denote the natural numbers \(\{0, 1, \ldots\}\) by \({\mathbb{N}}\). The symmetric group and full transformation semigroup on \(\{1, \ldots, n\}\), \(n\in {\mathbb{N}}\), are denoted \(S_n\) and \(T_n\), respectively. A subsemigroup of a semigroup \(S\) is monogenic if it can be generated by a single element; monogenic subsemigroups of finite groups are just cyclic subgroups. Let \(\mathbf{s},\mathbf{t}: {\mathbb{N}}{\longrightarrow}{\mathbb{N}}\) be defined by

item.title: Software
item.description:
GAP

  • Digraphs deposited GAP package, 2022.
  • Semigroups deposited GAP package, 2022.
  • SgpDec - Hierarchical composition and decomposition of finite permutation groups and transformation semigroups (by A. Egri-Nagy and C. Nehaniv with some contributions by me) deposited GAP package, 2022.
  • Smallsemi - a library of small semigroups (with A. Distler) deposited GAP package, 2022.

C++

  • libsemigroups C++ library for semigroups and monoids, 2022.

python

  • libsemigroups_pybind11 python package for using libsemigroups via pybind11, (with M. Tsalakou), 2022.
  • step_hen a rudimentary python implementation of Stephen’s procedure for inverse semigroups (with M. Tsalakou), 2021.
  • todd_coxeter.py reference implementation of the two main variants of the Todd-Coxeter algorithm for semigroups and monoids, 2021.
